newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian police froze $180,000 Minfin bonds.
newsitem.headline: Russian police froze $180,000 Minfin bonds.

text.p: Moscow police froze MinFin bonds with a face value of about $180,000 this month, a senior official at Vneshtorgbank, the main depositary for the bonds, said on Thursday.
"We have sent information to the main market participants about the recent police orders to freeze the bonds," Andrei Remnyov, deputy head of bank's depositary, told Reuters.

Remnyov said police from one Moscow city precinct had frozen $39,000 nominal of the second, third and fifth tranches of the bonds on May 7, and police from another precinct had frozen nearly $140,000 nominal of the fourth tranche of the bonds on May 13.
The second tranche of the bonds matured in 1996, but some are still being presented for repayment. The third tranche matures in 1999, the fourth tranche in 2003 and the fifth tranche in 2008.
The total nominal value of all MinFin bonds outstanding is $11 billion. Including the matured second tranche the value would be $13 billion.

Last year, the authorities froze about $74 million of bonds as part of an investigation into stolen bonds. The paper was subsequently unfrozen, but only after the move shook confidence in the market, causing a fall in prices.
